lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct jobs.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Give students three pictures of jobs. Read one job description aloud. Students hold up or point to the correct one.
stretchStrategies: Students interview 2–3 classmates about what job they want in the future. Then they report back: “She wants to be a ___.” “He wants to be a ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write about their own and their friends’ future jobs using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Ask students to complete: “I want to be a ___. My friend wants to be a ___.” Display sentence frame on board for reference.
stretchStrategies: Students interview 2–3 classmates about what job they want in the future. Then they report back: “She wants to be a ___.” “He wants to be a ___.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can present their friends’ future jobs to the class using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Presentation) Students draw themselves doing their dream job and say 1–2 sentences: “I want to be a ___ because ___.”
stretchStrategies: Students interview 2–3 classmates about what job they want in the future. Then they report back: “She wants to be a ___.” “He wants to be a ___.”

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
